answers.feedback_html: \Delta t = {{\Delta d} \over {{v_{avg}}}} = {{205\,m} \over {1.40\,m/s}} = 146\,s
Cassie walks 1.40 m in 1 second. Think of how many seconds she will take to cover 205 m.

answers.content_html: 2.50 min

stem_html: Cassie walked to her friend’s house with an average speed of 1.40 m/s. The distance between the houses is 205 m. How long did the trip take her?

answers.content_html: No, it reflects speed but not the direction.
answers.feedback_html: Instantaneous velocity has a magnitude as well as a direction, both of which cannot be determined from the speedometer reading.

answers.content_html: No, it reflects the average speed of the car.
answers.feedback_html: The speedometer reading changes rapidly, as soon as the car speeds up or slows down.

answers.content_html: Yes, it sometimes reflects instantaneous velocity of the car.
answers.feedback_html: The speedometer reading does not give the direction of the car.

answers.feedback_html: The speedometer reading does not give the direction of the car.

stem_html: Is it possible to determine a car’s instantaneous velocity from just the speedometer reading?

answers.feedback_html: Recall that the distance traveled is average speed multiplied by the time taken.
The time can be obtained using the fact that average speed v_{avg} is given by v_{avg} = distance/time.

answers.content_html: 3t
answers.feedback_html: The distance covered by Rob in both journeys is the same. So, if speed has increased by 3 times, then by how much should the time be reduced to make the distance constant.

answers.content_html: 6t

stem_html: Rob drove to the nearest hospital with an average speed of v m/s in t seconds. In terms of t, if he drives home on the same path, but with an average speed of 3v m/s, how long is the return trip home?

answers.content_html: Reduce the distance that the object travels by half, keeping the time constant, or keep the distance constant and double the time.
answers.feedback_html: Average speed is the distance traveled per unit time. So reducing distance by keeping time constant will decrease the average velocity. Similarly, increasing time by keeping distance constant will also decrease average speed.

answers.content_html: Double the distance that the object travels, keeping the time constant, or keep the distance constant and reduce the time by half.
answers.feedback_html: To double the average speed, double the distance and keep the time constant, or reduce the time by half and keep distance constant.

answers.content_html: Reduce the distance that the object travels to one-fourth, keeping the time constant, or keep the distance constant and increase the time by fourfold.
answers.feedback_html: Average speed is directly proportional to the distance covered if time is constant, and it is inversely proportional to time if distance is kept constant. So, reducing distance or increasing time decreases the average speed.

answers.content_html: Increase the distance by fourfold, keeping the time constant, or keep the distance constant and reduce the time by one-fourth.
answers.feedback_html: Average speed is directly proportional to the distance covered if time is constant, and it is inversely proportional to time if distance is kept constant. So, making the distance 4 times or reducing the time by one-fourth will make the average speed 4 times the initial value.

stem_html: An object has an average speed of 7.4 km/h. Which of the following describes two ways you could increase the average speed of the object to 14.8 km/h?

answers.content_html: Runner A will be 72 \times 10^3 m away and Runner B will be 59.5 \times 10^3 m away from the starting point.
answers.feedback_html: The average speed of A and B is not correct.

answers.content_html: Runner A will be 1.2 \times 10^2 m away and runner B will be 1.1 \times 10^2 m away from the starting point.
answers.feedback_html: Check the distance of Runner B.

answers.content_html: Runner A will be 1.2 \times 10^2\,\text{m} away and Runner B will be 1.3 \times 10^2\,\text{m} away from the starting point.
answers.feedback_html: Average speed is distance covered per unit time and distance covered can be found by taking the product of average speed and time.

answers.content_html: Runner A will be 7.2 \times 10^2\,\text{m} away and Runner B will be 1.3 \times 10^2\,\text{m} away from the starting point.
answers.feedback_html: At time t = 45\,\text{s}, the time interval for Runner A will be 45 - 0 = 45\,\text{s} and the time interval for Runner B will be 45 - 2.5 = 42.5\,\text{s}. So, the distance covered by Runner A in this time interval will be 2.6\,\text{m/s} \times 45\,\text{s}.

stem_html: Two runners start at the same point and jog at a constant speed along a straight path. Runner A starts at time t = 0 s, and Runner B starts at time t = 2.5 s. The runners both reach a distance 64 m from the starting point at time t = 25 s. If the runners continue at the same speeds, how far from the starting point will each be at time t = 45 s?
